StringWithMarkup.String: Workers at a creosote impregnation plant for lumber were exposed to an average atmospheric concentration of acenaphthene of 2.2 mg/cu m for 18 samples(1). The concentration of acenaphthene in the personal air at the coal preparation area of a solvent refined coal pilot plant was 2.3, 1.0 and 0.8 ug/cu m for a welder and two operators, respectively(2). Acenaphthene was found to be completely in the gaseous phase in the workplace air of an aluminum plant at Soderberg, Norway at an average concentrationug/cu m(3). Workers in the paving, roofing and steel industries are exposed to average acenaphthene concentration in the air of less than 1 ug/cu m in the gaseous phase(4). Workers in the aluminum refineries, silicon carbide and refractory brick industries are exposed to average acenaphthene concentration in the air of less than 100 ug/cu m in the gaseous phase(4). Atmospheric concentration of acenaphthene were 0.41, 0.01 and 0.92 mg/cu m for the preparation area, cleaning floor and Acheson furnace of a silicon carbide plant(5). The emission source of an Acheson furnace at a silicon carbide plant released acenaphthene into the indoor air at a concentration of 13.0 and 20.0 ug/cu m for gas and particulate phase, respectively(5). Ambient air of the plant averaged gaseous acenaphthene at 0.19 ug/cu m(5).

Reference: Ellenhorn, M.J. and D.G. Barceloux. Medical Toxicology - Diagnosis and Treatment of Human Poisoning. New York, NY: Elsevier Science Publishing Co., Inc. 1988., p. 953

StringWithMarkup.String: Coke oven, coal tar, pitch, asphalt fume, & carbon black workers are all exposed to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. /Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons/

Reference: El-Mubarak AH et al; Environ Sci Pollut Res Int Aug 6 (2016)

StringWithMarkup.String: The main objectives of this work were to identify and determine the concentrations of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and trace metals in carpet dust samples from various mosques of the city of Riyadh and to assess the health risks associated with the exposure to these pollutants. Therefore, 31 samples of mosque's carpet dust from Riyadh were collected. The results showed that 14 PAHs were present in the dust samples with concentrations ranged from 90 to 22,146 ng/g (mean = 4096 ng/g) where low molecular weight compounds were dominant. The presence of PAHs were in the order of naphthalene > chrysene and benzo(b)fluoranthene > benzo(a)pyrene > acenaphthene and benzo(k)fluoranthene > pyrene and the absence of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene and dibenz(a,h)anthracene. The diagnostic ratio coupled with principle component analysis (PCA) revealed mix sources of petrogenic from traffic, stack emission, and pyrogenic inputs from essence and perfumed wood burning. Trace metals were significant in the dust samples, and their concentrations decrease in the order of Zn, Mn, Cu, Cr, Pb, Ni, and V where Zn being the highest (94.4 ug/g) and indium was the lowest (1.9 ug/g). The trace metals were major in southern and central parts of Riyadh and followed the order of central Riyadh > southern Riyadh > western Riyadh > eastern Riyadh > northern Riyadh. Estimated risk based on the total PAHs was found to be 4.30X10-11 for adult and 1.56X10-11 for children. Elemental non-cancer risk for adults ranged from 7.9X10-4 for Co to 7.58X10-1 for Li and for children ranged from 3.70X10-3 for Co to 3.54 for Li. Policy implication and mitigations of PAHs in Riyadh and Saudi Arabia were highlighted.

StringWithMarkup.String: Human milk samples collected from 39 women in Beijing, China in 2005-2006 contained a mean acenaphthene concentration of 0.845 ng/g fresh weight(1); placenta collected from 27 women contained a mean acenaphthene concentration of 0.824 ng/g fresh weight(1); umbilical cord blood collected from 30 women contained a mean acenaphthene concentration of 0.229 ng/g fresh weight(1). Adipose tissue collected from Korean women in 2007-2008 contained a mean acenaphthene concentration of 6.4 ng/g lipid weight(2). Blood plasma collected from 111 human donors in Hong Kong in 2008 contained mean acenaphthene levels of 54.6 and 54.4 ng/g lipid in females and males respectively(3).

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
